com.bluegosling.reflect

Interface TypeAnnotationChecker

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    TypeAnnotationHierarchy
    Functional Interface:
    This is a functional interface and can therefore be used as the assignment target for a lambda expression or method reference.

    @FunctionalInterface
public interface TypeAnnotationChecker
    Checks if a given type annotation is assignable to another. If an annotation A1 is assignable to annotation A2, then a given annotated type @A1 T1 is assignable to another type @A2 T2 as long as T1 is assignable to T2 according to the Java type system. (See Types.isAssignable(java.lang.reflect.Type, java.lang.reflect.Type) for more info.)

    This can provide functionality similar to the Checker Framework, except that it works at runtime instead of compile-time and is backed by core reflection.

    See Also:
    TypeAnnotationHierarchy

    • Method Detail

      • isAssignable

        boolean isAssignable(Annotation from,
                     Annotation to)
        Determines if the given annotation is assignable to the other. Either or both annotations could be null, indicating unannotated types.

        Note that two equivalent types are mutually assignable. So if two annotations indicate the same type, then this method should return true regardless of the order of arguments.

        Parameters:
        from - annotation that appears on the type of the assignment source (RHS)
        to - annotation that appears on the type of the assignment target (LHS)
        Returns:
        true if a type annotated with to is assignable from a type annotated with from

      • isEquivalent

        default boolean isEquivalent(Annotation a1,
                             Annotation a2)
        Determines if the given two annotations are equivalent. Either or both annotations could be null, indicating unannotated types.

        The default implementation verifies that the first annotation is assignable to the second and vice versa: that the second is assignable to the first.

        Parameters:
        a1 - a type annotation
        a2 - another type annotation
        Returns:
        true if the the two type annotations are equivalent

      • isAssignable

        default boolean isAssignable(Collection<? extends Annotation> from,
                             Collection<? extends Annotation> to)
        Determines if the one set of annotations is assignable to a second set of annotations. If an annotation A1 is assignable from annotation A2, then a given annotated type @A1 T1 is assignable from another type @A2 T2 as long as T1 is assignable from T2 according to the Java type system. (See Types.isAssignable(java.lang.reflect.Type, java.lang.reflect.Type) for more info.)

        Note that two equivalent types are mutually assignable. So if two annotations indicate the same type, then this method should return true regardless of the order of arguments.

        An argument that is empty indicates the absence of any type annotations.

        The default implementation reduces the two sets of annotations to single annotations. If either set contains more than one annotation which is not equivalent to the others, then an exception is thrown since this indicates an invalid (or incompatible) set of annotations. Upon reduction, the single from and to annotations are checked via isAssignable(Annotation, Annotation).

        Parameters:
        from - annotations that appear on the type of the assignment source (RHS)
        to - annotations that appear on the type of the assignment target (LHS)
        Returns:
        true if a type annotated with to annotations is assignable from a type annotated with from annotations
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if either collection of annotations represents an illegal combination of type annotations (for example, contains both NotNull and Nullable)

      • isAssignable

        default boolean isAssignable(Annotation[] from,
                             Annotation[] to)
        Determines if a given set of annotations is assignable to a second set of annotations. This is a convenience method for use with core reflection, where most methods that query annotations return arrays, not collections.
        Parameters:
        from - annotations that appear on the type of the assignment source (RHS)
        to - annotations that appear on the type of the assignment target (LHS)
        Returns:
        true if a type annotated with to annotations is assignable from a type annotated with from annotations
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if either collection of annotations represents an illegal combination of type annotations (for example, contains both NotNull and Nullable)
        See Also:
        isAssignable(Collection, Collection)

      • isEquivalent

        default boolean isEquivalent(Collection<? extends Annotation> a1,
                             Collection<? extends Annotation> a2)
        Determines if a given set of annotations is equivalent to a second set of annotations. Note that two equivalent types are mutually assignable. So if two annotations indicate the same type, then this method should return true regardless of the order of arguments.

        An argument that is empty indicates the absence of any type annotations.

        The default implementation reduces the two sets of annotations to single annotations. If either set contains more than one annotation which is not equivalent to the others, then an exception is thrown since this indicates an invalid (or incompatible) set of annotations. Upon reduction, the single from and to annotations are checked via isEquivalent(Annotation, Annotation).

        Parameters:
        a1 - a set of annotations associated with a type
        a2 - another set of annotations associated with a type
        Returns:
        true if a type annotated with a1 annotations is equivalent to a type annotated with a2 annotations
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if either collection of annotations represents an illegal combination of type annotations (for example, contains both NotNull and Nullable)

      • isEquivalent

        default boolean isEquivalent(Annotation[] a1,
                             Annotation[] a2)
        Determines if a given set of annotations is equivalent to a second set of annotations. This is a convenience method for use with core reflection, where most methods that query annotations return arrays, not collections.
        Parameters:
        a1 - a set of annotations associated with a type
        a2 - another set of annotations associated with a type
        Returns:
        true if a type annotated with a1 annotations is equivalent to a type annotated with a2 annotations
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if either collection of annotations represents an illegal combination of type annotations (for example, contains both NotNull and Nullable)
        See Also:
        isEquivalent(Collection, Collection)

      • validateAnnotations

        default void validateAnnotations(Annotation[] annotations)
        Validates that the given set of annotations is consistent. This is a convenience method for use with core reflection, where most methods that query annotations return arrays, not collections.
        Parameters:
        annotations - a set of type annotations
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if either collection of annotations represents an illegal combination of type annotations (for example, contains both NotNull and Nullable)
        See Also:
        validateAnnotations(Collection)

      • validateAnnotations

        default void validateAnnotations(Collection<? extends Annotation> annotations)
        Validates that the given set of annotations is consistent. If the given annotations contains incompatible type annotations (e.g. both Nullable and NonNull) then an exception is thrown

        The default implementation verifies that all recognized annotations in the given set are equivalent. Otherwise, the set represents an invalid combination, and an exception is thrown.

        Parameters:
        annotations - a set of type annotations
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if either collection of annotations represents an illegal combination of type annotations (for example, contains both NotNull and Nullable)

      • and

        default TypeAnnotationChecker and(TypeAnnotationChecker other)
        Combines two checkers into one. Sets of annotations are only assignable if both this and the given checker both agree they are assignable.
        Parameters:
        other - another annotation checker
        Returns:
        a new checker that considers annotations assignable only when both this and the given checker agree they are assignable
